title: Efficient Transformer Variants for Edge Deployment
bit: Transformer models are too large and slow for edge devices
flip: Develop compressed transformer variants using knowledge distillation and quantization
hypothesis: A 10x smaller transformer can maintain 95% of performance through careful distillation and 8-bit quantization
evaluationPlan:
1. Baseline: Measure BERT-base performance on GLUE benchmark
2. Apply knowledge distillation with temperature scaling
3. Implement 8-bit quantization with QAT
4. Measure: model size, inference latency, GLUE scores
5. Statistical tests: paired t-tests on each GLUE task
expectedOutcomes:
- Model size: 440MB → 44MB
- Inference time: 50ms → 5ms
- GLUE score: 82.5 → 78.4 (95% retention)
risksAndMitigation:
Risk: Catastrophic performance drop on specific tasks
Mitigation: Task-specific fine-tuning after compression
timeline: 4 weeks: 1 week setup, 2 weeks experiments, 1 week analysis

title: Ferrofluid vs. Traditional Iron Bioavailability Core Test
bit: Iron must be in dissolved ionic or chelated form to be plant-available
flip: Ferrofluids provide superior iron delivery through colloidal suspension with enhanced bioavailability
hypothesis: Ferrofluid-delivered iron will show 20-40% higher plant uptake efficiency compared to Fe-EDDHA under controlled hydroponic conditions
evaluationPlan:
1. Hydroponic wheat seedling trials with randomized complete block design
2. Compare ferrofluid (10nm, 20nm, 50nm) vs Fe-EDDHA vs Fe-DTPA vs control
3. Measure: SPAD chlorophyll, leaf/root Fe content (ICP-MS), biomass, iron use efficiency
4. Statistical analysis: ANOVA with Tukey HSD post-hoc
5. 14-day monitoring with daily SPAD readings
expectedOutcomes:
- 20-40% higher iron content in ferrofluid-treated plants
- Faster chlorophyll recovery (2+ days earlier peak)
- Superior iron use efficiency
- Optimal particle size identification
risksAndMitigation:
Risk: pH changes affecting uptake → Buffer all solutions to pH 6.5
Risk: Nanoparticle aggregation → DLS verification
Risk: Observer bias → Blinded measurements
relatedWork: Magnetite nanoparticles in plant nutrition (Ghafariyan et al., 2013)
Iron oxide nanoparticle uptake (Pradhan et al., 2013)
vectors: Highest risk: Core assumption of superior bioavailability - if false, invalidates entire approach
timeline: 4 weeks: 1 week setup, 2 weeks treatment, 1 week analysis
notes: Foundation experiment - must succeed for program viability

title: Magnetic Field-Guided Precision Iron Delivery
bit: Nanoparticle uptake by plants is passive and uncontrollable
flip: Magnetic field guidance enables precise, controllable nanoparticle delivery to specific plant tissues
hypothesis: Magnetic field application will increase iron accumulation in targeted leaf sectors by 30-50% compared to non-guided application
evaluationPlan:
1. Split-leaf design with magnetic field (50, 100, 200 mT) applied to leaf sectors
2. Ferrofluid foliar application + 2-hour magnetic exposure
3. Spatial analysis: LA-ICP-MS iron mapping, TEM nanoparticle localization
4. Measure iron gradients and chlorophyll spatial recovery
5. Statistical comparison of field-exposed vs control sectors
expectedOutcomes:
- >30% higher iron in magnetically-targeted tissues
- Visible directional iron gradients on spatial maps
- Proof-of-concept for precision agriculture applications
risksAndMitigation:
Risk: Magnetic field plant damage → Control groups with field-only exposure
Risk: Equipment interference → Scheduled analytical access
Risk: Insufficient spatial resolution → Method validation with standards
relatedWork: Magnetic targeting in drug delivery (Pankhurst et al., 2003)
Plant responses to magnetic fields (Galland & Pazur, 2005)
Nanoparticle plant uptake mechanisms (Kurepa et al., 2010)
vectors: Technical risk: Magnetic guidance effectiveness - determines precision agriculture potential
timeline: 3 weeks: 1 week setup, 1 week treatment, 1 week analysis
notes: Builds on Experiment 1 results - novel targeting capability

title: Economic Viability vs Commercial Chelates
bit: Expensive synthetic chelates are necessary for effective iron delivery in alkaline soils
flip: Ferrofluids can provide cost-effective iron delivery matching or exceeding chelate performance at lower cost
hypothesis: Ferrofluid treatments will achieve equivalent chlorosis correction at 50% lower cost per treated hectare compared to Fe-EDDHA
evaluationPlan:
1. Field-scale randomized trials (1m² plots, n=5) across soil types
2. Compare ferrofluid vs Fe-EDDHA vs Fe-DTPA at multiple doses
3. Economic tracking: material costs, application costs, yield impacts
4. Measure: chlorosis recovery time, grain yield, iron persistence, efficacy duration
5. Cost-effectiveness analysis: yield improvement per dollar spent
expectedOutcomes:
- Equivalent yield at <50% cost vs Fe-EDDHA
- Extended treatment efficacy (>20% longer duration)
- Superior cost-effectiveness ratio
risksAndMitigation:
Risk: Weather variability → Multi-season replication
Risk: Scale-up cost differences → Realistic production cost modeling
Risk: Plot edge effects → 50cm buffer zones
vectors: Commercial risk: Cost competitiveness - determines market adoption potential
timeline: 12 weeks: 2 weeks setup, 8 weeks growing season, 2 weeks analysis

title: Environmental Safety and Biodegradability Assessment
bit: Environmental persistence is the inevitable cost of effective iron treatments
flip: Biodegradable ferrofluid formulations provide effective treatment without long-term environmental accumulation
hypothesis: Biodegradable ferrofluids will degrade to safe levels within 60 days while maintaining plant iron status
evaluationPlan:
1. Soil microcosm studies with biodegradable vs synthetic coatings
2. Environmental conditions: aerobic/anaerobic, temperature gradients
3. Monitor: nanoparticle degradation (SP-ICP-MS), microbial communities (16S rRNA)
4. Ecotoxicity: earthworm bioaccumulation, plant growth during degradation
5. Kinetic modeling of degradation pathways
expectedOutcomes:
- >90% nanoparticle degradation within 60 days
- No adverse microbial diversity impacts
- Sustained plant iron benefits during degradation
risksAndMitigation:
Risk: Microcosm artifacts → Validation in soil columns
Risk: Detection limits → Method validation with spiked samples
Risk: Incomplete degradation → Multiple coating chemistries tested
vectors: Regulatory risk: Environmental safety approval required for commercialization
timeline: 12 weeks: 2 weeks setup, 8 weeks monitoring, 2 weeks analysis
notes: Parallel with cost study - addresses sustainability concerns
